title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
What is Git?

Program to track file changes and create a history of those changes
Creates a ‘container’ for a set of files called a repository

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
What is GitHub?

Collaborative software designed to organize files and track changes by different people through time
Built on top of Git
Allows to sync (clone) Git repositories locally and over the web

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Why use Git and GitHub?

Version control - for you and others
Collaboration - within your team and among colleagues and peers outside of your team
Project management - collaborative “to-do” lists
Publishing platform - README files and GitHub Pages

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Git and GitHub: The Basics

Repositories - the main unit

Sets the folder and file structure
Contained and permissioned
Public or private

Users and organizations
Commits and issues - Contributing through GitHub

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
What is a “commit”?

A specific “thing” that you want to save and keep a record for
Snapshot of all the files in the entire project
Commit messages provide info about the “thing” you’ve done

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Forking

Contributing to someone else’s repository
“Sees” changes from parent repo - allows syncing with parent
Can be for personal purposes - doesn’t have to be pushed to original repo!

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Cloning

Making a local copy from GitHub
Allows local sync within and across devices

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Importing

Use another repo as starting point for your own
Copy not connected to original

title: What are Git and GitHub?
text:
Branching

Copies of repos housed within the repo structure
Allow for working on repo without changing main branch
Can help for more complex collaboration

title: GitHub for Project Management
section: Why use GitHub for project management?
text:
Why use GitHub for project management?

Issues and projects stoke collaboration
Issues act as short-term to-do lists
Projects capture longer-term goals and organize short-term issues

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Issues

Tasks for things to do
Place to provide detail
Checklists, labels, tags

title: GitHub for Project Management
text:
Projects

Group issues to view everything together
Work across repositories

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
What is GitHub Enterprise?

An account with GitHub organizations (orgs) that has more controls than GitHub Free.
Your personal GitHub account can have repos in GitHub Free orgs or GitHub Enterprise orgs.
Your identity (username) does not change – as long as your user account uses your noaa.gov email.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise different?

It is controlled by work and has more rules
It requires CAC sign-in.
It requires a license.
Outside (non NOAA) collaborators have to be added by an admin to repos. They use a license if the repo is private or internal.
GitHub 3rd party applications require approval

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise different?

It is more security since it has CAC sign-in
It has more features: private and internal GitHub Pages, more GitHub Action minutes, bigger files allowed.
Allows internal repositories only visible to NMFS GitHub users across GHEC. See code from other science centers (if they made it internal)
Collaborate on repos with any other NMFS GHEC org. You can be on orgs at other centers
Has IT managed automatic backups.
NMFS doesn’t lose code due to repo owner leaving NOAA
FedRAMP approved unlike GitHub free

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
section: How is GitHub Enterprise not different?
text:
How is GitHub Enterprise not different?

You can create repos just like in GitHub Free
You have access to the usual collaboration tools: projects, GitHub Actions, GitHub Pages
You are admin on your own repos and can admin them as usual…except re outside collaborators.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Signing up for GHEC

Follow the instructions on the GGT website to request access.
Wait to be invited to GHEC and accept
Then you can sign in to an org like https://github.com/noaa-nwfsc with CAC or password+authentication

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC
Using GitHub Desktop

Go to GitHub Desktop > Settings > Accounts
Sign into GitHub.com. Ignore GitHub Enterprise!!
DONE!

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC
Using GitHub Desktop

Help! I signed up for GitHub Enterprise and GitHub Desktop will not authenticate!! Log out of GitHub Desktop under GitHub Desktop > Settings (or Options) > Account and log back in.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Tell RStudio about Git

In RStudio, Tools > Terminal > New Terminal
At the command line (in the new terminal), type which git if on a Mac and where git if in Windows.
Copy that path.
In RStudio, Tools > Global Options > Git/SVN There is a box at top that asks for the location of the Git binary.
Paste that path in.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
You have to authenticate to GitHub separately for RStudio even if you are signed in on GitHub Desktop.
If you see anything like this, you have not authenticated.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Set up

Install usethis R package
Run this code:

usethis::use_git_config(user.name = "your username", user.email = "you@noaa.gov")

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Create Token
usethis::create_github_token(
  scopes = c("repo", "workflow"),
  description = "DESCRIBE THE TOKEN'S USE CASE",
  host = NULL
)

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Create Token

Set the date when the token will expire.
Scroll to bottom and click “Generate token”
Copy the long PAT.

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Configure PAT for GHEC

Next to the PAT, you will see “Configure for SSO”.
Click that and authenticate to your GHEC org

title: Intro to GitHub Enterprise
text:
Authenticating to GHEC: Using RStudio
Tell RSTudio about the PAT
Run this code.
credentials::set_github_pat("THE LONG PAT)

title: Putting Everything Together
section: Practice creating a repository for your own project
text:
Practice creating a repository for your own project

Open GitHub Desktop
Login with your GitHub account (if you have not already done so)
Create a new repository
Move your code and other project files into your new repository
Make a commit with your initial files
Push your commit up to GitHub

title: Putting Everything Together
section: Practice creating a repository for your own project
text:
Practice creating a repository for your own project

Open the repository in your browser
Add your teammates as collaborators
Create an issue and tag a teammate
Make a change to the README and commit in a new branch
Create a pull request
Merge the pull request into your main branch

title: Reuse Statement
text:
This content is released under CC0 Creative Commons.
Permissive Re-Mix and No Attribution Needed: You may reuse the content in this repository—excluding the NMFS Open Science logo and any NOAA logos—in any way you like. You do not need permission. You do not need to give attribution, but if you use large parts of tutorials or content it is polite to give acknowledgement of the source. Please check each NMFS Open Science repository for its reuse statement. Some of the content is from Carl Boettiger and from NASA Openscapes. This will be noted and you should check the original content for its reuse statement.
